metadata.case_name: State of Gujarat v. Company (First Respondent)

facts.text: The Bombay Labour Welfare Fund Act, 1953 was passed by the legislature of the then State of Bombay to constitute a fund for financing activities for promoting the welfare of labour.

Section 2(10) of the Act defined 'unpaid accumulations' as all payments due to employees but not made within three years from the date they became due, including wages and gratuity, but excluding provident fund contributions.
Section 3(1) provided for constitution of the Labour Welfare Fund, and s.3(2)(b) included all unpaid accumulations in the Fund.

In Bombay Dyeing & Manufacturing Co. Ltd. v. State of Bombay (1958 SCR 1122), this Court held ss.3(1) and 3(2)(b) invalid as violating Art.19(1)(f), due to transfer of debts to Board without discharging employer liability and lack of adjudication machinery.
On May 1, 1960, State of Bombay bifurcated into Maharashtra and Gujarat.

Gujarat Legislature enacted First Amendment Act in 1961 with retrospective effect to remedy defects from Bombay Dyeing case; amended definitions of employee, employer, establishment; s.2(4) defines establishment as factory, tramway/motor omnibus service, or any establishment employing >50 persons (excluding govt establishments other than factories).
Amended s.3 requires unpaid accumulations to be collected and paid to Board, which keeps separate account until claims decided under s.6A.

New s.6A deems unpaid accumulations as abandoned property; payment to Board discharges employer liability to that extent, transfers to Board; Board publishes notice inviting claims for 3 years, transfers claims to authority under Payment of Wages Act for adjudication; unclaimed after 4 years or rejected claims vest in State as bona vacantia.
During writ pendency, Gujarat enacted Second Amendment Act, 1962 (effective Feb 5, 1963) adding s.6A(13) retrospectively exempting certain pre-paid accumulations.
Rules 3 and 4 concern machinery for enforcing fines and unpaid accumulations; amended to include particulars for s.6A(3) notice.

First respondent (company) filed writ petition in Gujarat High Court impugning ss.3,6A,7 of Act, s.13 of First Amendment Act, rules 3,4 as unconstitutional; challenged notice dated Aug 2, 1962 by Welfare Commissioner requiring payment of unpaid accumulations.
Gujarat High Court by judgment dated July 19/20/21, 1965 held s.3(1) insofar as relating to unpaid accumulations in s.3(2)(b), s.3(4), s.6A and rules 3,4 unconstitutional and void.
Facts similar in all appeals; decision in CA 2271/1968 disposes others.

Affidavit by Mr. Brahmbhatt (Deputy Secretary) explained differentiation: higher labour turnover in factories; few govt establishments carrying business; tramways/omnibuses employ large labour and keep records.

legal_issues.text: Whether impugned provisions violate fundamental rights of citizen-employers/employees under Art.19(1)(f), rendering law void under Art.13(2), so no law exists and notice to non-citizen company is without authority of law.
Whether definition of 'establishment' in s.2(4) violates Art.14 by unreasonable classification.

petitioner_arguments.text: Impugned provisions violate Art.19(1)(f) of citizen-employers/employees, void under Art.13(2); no law exists, notice unauthorised.

Definition of establishment in s.2(4) discriminatory under Art.14: includes factories (even small), tramways/omnibuses (even <50), govt factories but excludes other govt establishments and commercial <50 persons; no intelligible differentia or nexus.

respondent_arguments.text: Higher labour turnover in factories justifies inclusion; small accumulations in <50 commercial establishments; few govt non-factory business establishments; tramways/omnibuses have large labour, keep records.

court_reasoning.text: Unpaid accumulations deemed abandoned property under s.6A(1); Board takes over, publishes notice, adjudicates claims over 4 years; unclaimed vests as bona vacantia after 7 years total; reasonable period, sufficient notice.
court_reasoning.key_observation: 7-year period adequate; State substitution as debtor not unconstitutional burden.

court_reasoning.text: Company (non-citizen) cannot challenge on citizens' Art.19(1)(f) rights; law void only qua citizens whose rights infringed, operative qua non-citizens; precedents (Keshava Menon, Behram Pesikaka, etc.) support: void to extent of contravention of citizens' rights.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Art.13(2) voidness confined to persons/entities whose Part III rights abrogated; valid for non-citizens.

court_reasoning.text: s.2(4) classification reasonable: factories (high turnover, records) included fully; commercial >50 for admin convenience (larger accumulations); tramways/omnibuses similar (large labour, records); govt non-factories negligible.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Under-inclusive ok for economic regulation; legislature may proceed stepwise; judicial deference.

court_reasoning.text: Even if tramways inclusion bad, severable; but justified by records under Payment of Wages Act.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Classification addresses purpose: collect unpaid accumulations efficiently for labour welfare.

holdings.text: Impugned provisions do not violate Art.19(1)(f) of citizens or render law void qua non-citizens; valid law applicable to companies.
Definition of 'establishment' in s.2(4) does not violate Art.14; reasonable classification.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court allowed the appeals, set aside Gujarat High Court judgment holding parts of the Act unconstitutional; upheld validity of impugned provisions against challenges under Arts.14 and 19(1)(f); provisions constitutional and applicable to non-citizen companies.

key_quotes.text: "even though a law which is inconsistent with fundamental rights under article 19 would become void after the commencement of the Constitution, the law would still continue in force in so far as non-citizens are concerned."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on Art.13 voidness limited to citizens.

key_quotes.text: "the voidness is not in rem but to the extent only of inconsistency or contravention, as the case may be of the rights conferred under Part III."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "A reasonable classification is one which includes all persons who are similarly situated with respect to the purpose of the law."
key_quotes.speaker: court
